questions.text: Which one of the following conditions causes hypokalemia in association with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 11 Beta hydroxylase deficiency will lead to the accumulation of deoxycorticosterone, which would cause hypokalemiawith hypertension
  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency leads to hypotension with hyperkalemiadue to a lack of both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoids (Option B)
  • Gitelman and Bartter syndrome would cause hypokalemia, but with hypotension (Options A and C ruled out)

Hypokalemia and hypertension

  • Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism)
  • Liddle's syndrome
  • 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency
  • 17-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Cushing syndrome
  • Liquorice ingestion

Hypokalemia without hypertension

  • Diuretics
  • GI loss (e.g., diarrhoea, vomiting)
  • Renal tubular acidosis (type 1)
  • Bartter's syndrome
  • Gitelman syndrome

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents with a nine-month history of weight gain. Prior to this he was of a normal weight and cannot identify any obvious lifestyle changes that would account for his obesity. On examination he is noted to have abdominal striae and a degree of proximal myopathy. Blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Bloods show the following:

What is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cushing's syndrome is characterised by features such as central obesity, proximal myopathy, and abdominal striae.
  • The 24-hour urinary free cortisol test is the most appropriate initial confirmatory test, as it measures cortisol secretion over an entire day, eliminating diurnal variation.
  • High-dose dexamethasone suppression test: Used later to differentiate causes (pituitary vs ectopic vs adrenal). (Option A ruled out)
  • Plasma ACTH: Helpful for classification after diagnosis, but not first-line. (Option B ruled out)
  • Renin: aldosterone ratio: Used to assess primary hyperaldosteronism, not Cushing's syndrome. (Option D ruled out)
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis is seen in severe cases of Cushing syndrome due to the action of cortisol on mineralocorticoid receptors in renal tubules.
  1. Tests to confirm Cushing's syndrome
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (most sensitive)
  • 24 hr urinary free cortisol
  • Midnight salivary cortisol
  • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
  1. Plasma ACTH level
  • Suppressed ACTH in a patient with Cushing syndrome is suggestive of an adrenal cause (Adrenal adenoma/carcinoma) while a normal/elevated ACTH suggests an ACTH-dependent condition (pituitary adenoma / ectopic ACTH production).
  • If ACTH independent, a CT scan of the abdomen is performed to identify the adrenal pathology
  1. Localisation of ACTH-dependent cause
  • High-dose dexamethasone suppression test
    • If the pituitary source, then cortisol will decrease after high-dose Dexa
    • If the ectopic source for ACTH, then no change in cortisol
  • CRH stimulation:
    • If the pituitary source for ACTH, then ACTH and cortisol rise following CRH
    • If ectopic/adrenal, then no change in cortisol and ACTH
  • Inferior petrosal sinus sampling of ACTH may be needed to differentiate between pituitary and ectopic ACTH secretion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is admitted with a blood pressure of 226/120. She has a sinus tachycardia of HR 170 with intermittent runs of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia. 24-hour urine shows increased Adrenaline of 720 (<80 nmol/24 hours) and Noradrenaline of 2300 (<780 nmol/24 hours). Which one of the following medications would be most useful?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is in pheochromocytoma crisis, presenting with hypertensive emergency and catecholamine-induced arrhythmias.
  • Intravenous sodium nitroprusside is the drug of choice for rapid control of blood pressure as it acts as a direct arterial and venous vasodilator with an immediate onset of action.
  • Definitive management involves tumour resection, but acute stabilisation requires effective BP control with vasodilators.

Explanation of other options:

Intravenous labetalol (Option A): Contraindicated initially, β-blockade without prior α-blockade may precipitate unopposed α-adrenergic stimulation and worsen hypertension.

Intravenous amiodarone (Option B): Useful for arrhythmia suppression, but does not address the life-threatening hypertensive crisis.

Intravenous diltiazem (Option D): Can control heart rate but is not effective for severe catecholamine-induced hypertension.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady has increasing hirsutism. Her voice is becoming deeper. An ultrasound of the pelvis was unremarkable. Her serum testosterone was 2.1 ng/ml (normal <0.6 ng/ml), and Serum DHEAS was 982 mcg/dl (normal: 35-200). Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rapid onset of hirsutism with features of virilisation suggests an androgen-secreting tumour.
  • Elevated testosterone may be seen in both adrenal and ovarian tumours, but markedly elevated DHEAS is specific for adrenal tumours.
  • A normal pelvic ultrasound reduces the likelihood of an ovarian tumour.
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) usually presents earlier in life and is characterised by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone, making it unlikely in this patient. (Option D ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Option A (Ovarian tumour): Possible with high testosterone but less likely here due to high DHEAS and normal pelvic imaging.

Option B (PCOS): Typically presents with gradual hirsutism and mild androgen elevation, not rapid virilisation with very high DHEAS.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female is being evaluated for excessive weight gain. She has central obesity, abdominal striae, and hirsutism. An 8 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test was performed. Her 9 AM cortisol levels on Day 9 remained elevated at 970 nmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cushing's disease refers to pituitary-dependent hypercortisolism due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.
  • In the dexamethasone suppression test, normal individuals suppress cortisol to < 50 nmol/L.
  • About 90% of patients with pituitary-dependent disease show suppression of cortisol > 50% of baseline after high-dose dexamethasone.
  • The persistence of high cortisol here despite suppression indicates Cushing's disease.

Explanation of other options:

Adrenal adenoma (Option A): Causes ACTH-independent Cushing's syndrome with low ACTH and high cortisol, not seen here.

Ectopic ACTH (Option B): Seen with small cell lung carcinoma or carcinoid; usually shows very high ACTH levels and no suppression even with high-dose dexamethasone.

Conn's syndrome (Option D): Refers to primary hyperaldosteronism with hypertension and hypokalaemia, not features of cortisol excess.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with altered consciousness. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, his skin is pigmented, and he has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. His family say he has been tired for several months and has been losing weight and complaining of abdominal pain. Which of the following results is most likely to be found on investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease), suggested by hypotension, pigmentation, weight loss, abdominal pain and a history of another autoimmune disorder (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis).
  • Hyponatremia is a classical finding due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, causing sodium loss and volume depletion.
  • Addison's disease worldwide is most commonly autoimmune; in India, tuberculosis remains the leading cause.

Explanation of other options:

Option A (Glucose 298 mg/dL): Addison's causes hypoglycemia, not hyperglycemia, due to cortisol deficiency.

Option C (Decreased eosinophil count): Addison's is associated with eosinophilia, not a decrease, because of absent glucocorticoid-mediated suppression.

Option D (Potassium 2.4 mmol/L): Addison's typically causes hyperkalemia (increase in K+ due to mineralocorticoid deficiency), not hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of anorexia and weight loss, excess pigmentation and dizziness on standing. Initial investigations reveal hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia. Which of the following tests will be most useful to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is characterised by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and hyperpigmentation.
  • The short Synacthen test (ACTH stimulation test) is the gold standard for confirming adrenal insufficiency.
  • Synacthen (recombinant ACTH 1-24) is administered, and serum cortisol is measured.
  • Failure of serum cortisol to rise above the cutoff confirms adrenal failure.

Explanation of other options:

Plasma metanephrines (Option A): Used for the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, not adrenal insufficiency.

Thyroid function tests (Option B): Addison's can coexist with autoimmune thyroid disease (part of APS type II), but TFTs are not diagnostic for adrenal insufficiency.

Aldosterone renin ratio (Option C): Used for diagnosing primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome), not Addison's.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with intermittent weakness and feelings of tiredness. Her family physician requested some blood tests and found her to have a potassium level of 2.8 mmol/l and a bicarbonate of 32 mmol/l. She is normotensive. You arrange a renin and aldosterone level, and both are elevated. Urinary calcium excretion is elevated. Urinary diuretic screen is negative. Which diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Bartter's syndrome is characterised by hypokalaemia, metabolic alkalosis, elevated renin and aldosterone levels, but patients remain normotensive due to a renal tubular defect.
  • Increased urinary calcium excretion helps differentiate Bartter's from Gitelman's syndrome, where hypocalciuria is more typical. (Option B ruled out)
  • Diuretic abuse can mimic Bartter's syndrome, but a negative urinary diuretic screen rules this out. (Option A ruled out)
  • Liddle's syndrome presents with hypertension and suppressed renin and aldosterone, which is not consistent here. (Option C)
  • The absence of hypertension and presence of hypercalciuria point strongly to Bartter's syndrome.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with hypertension that is refractory to 3 anti-hypertensive medications.. The treating physician is concerned about the possibility of Conn's syndrome. The blood picture is one of metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and low renin and aldosterone levels. What diagnosis fits with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gordon's syndrome, also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterised by hypertension, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and low renin and aldosterone levels.
  • Addison's disease presents with hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation due to primary adrenal insufficiency. (Option C ruled out)
  • Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is associated with hypertension, metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and suppressed renin with elevated aldosterone. (Option D ruled out)

INHERITED RENAL TUBULAR DEFECTS

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman is referred to the clinic with difficult to manage hypertension. She is currently taking indapamide, Ramipril, amlodipine and doxazosin, yet her blood pressure is still 155/95 mmHg. On examination she has a BMI of 25. Ophthalmoscopy reveals evidence of Stage 3 hypertensive retinopathy. Blood reports reveal;Hb 14.0g/dl, WCC 5800/mm³, PLT 184000/mm³, Na+ 139mmol/l, K+ 3.1mmol/l and Creatinine 1 mg/dl. Her USG abdomen and Renal artery Doppler testing was normal. What would be your next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has resistant hypertension despite 4 antihypertensive agents, with end-organ damage (retinopathy) and hypokalemia, suggesting primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • The aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR) is the screening test of choice for diagnosing primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • CT/MRI abdomen may help in distinguishing between bilateral adrenal hyperplasia and adenoma, but ARR is the initial step before imaging.
  • Antihypertensive drugs can alter ARR values, so ideally, testing should be performed after stopping interfering medications.
  • A low renin with inappropriately high aldosterone confirms the diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism.

Explanation of other options:

CT Abdomen (Option A): Helps differentiate cause (adenoma vs hyperplasia) but is not the initial screening test.

Plasma metanephrines (Option B): Used for diagnosing pheochromocytoma, which is not suspected here.

Morning cortisol (Option D): Used in screening for Cushing's syndrome, which is not suggested by the history.

questions.text: A 38-year-old labourer is admitted to the Emergency Room after falling off his ladder. History of note includes hypertension, which is managed with nifedipine 10 mg daily. The Emergency scan reveals a 4 cm right-sided adrenal mass. His blood pressure in the Emergency room is 145/90 mmHg. Blood results: Hb 12.1 g/dl, WCC 6200/mm3, PLT 232000/mm3, Na+ 138 mmol/l, K+ 2.6 mmol/l, Creatinine 0.8 mg/dl. Which of the following would be most likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypertension, along with an adrenal mass, raises suspicion for an aldosterone-producing adenoma or pheochromocytoma.
  • Hypokalemia strongly favours the diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • Plasma aldosterone: renin ratio (ARR) is the screening test of choice for diagnosing primary hyperaldosteronism.
  • Primary hyperaldosteronism accounts for 10-15% of secondary hypertension cases, more common than previously thought.
  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia is more common than Conn's adenoma, but both present with similar biochemical findings.

Explanation of other options:

24-hr Urinary catecholamines (Option A): Used to detect pheochromocytoma, not the first test when hypokalemia is present.

Urinary sodium (Option C): Not specific for adrenal pathology; reflects renal handling of sodium.

MRI adrenals (Option D): Useful for localisation, but only after biochemical confirmation of disease.

questions.text: A patient with Addison's disease presents with an acute onset of diarrhoea and vomiting. He currently takes fludrocortisone and hydrocortisone. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patients on glucocorticoid replacement therapy should be instructed to double their dose during episodes of febrile illness, accident, or significant stress.
  • If the patient is vomiting and cannot take oral medication, parenteral hydrocortisone must be administered urgently.
  • IV fluids are necessary to correct dehydration and prevent Addisonian crisis.
  • There is no need to increase the fludrocortisone dose during stress or intercurrent illness.
  • Prompt treatment prevents life-threatening adrenal crisis.

Explanation of other options:

IV metoclopramide (Option A): Helps nausea/vomiting but does not correct the underlying adrenal crisis.

IV ondansetron (Option B): Symptomatic antiemetic, but not life-saving in Addison's crisis.

Increase fludrocortisone (Option D): Not indicated in acute stress; glucocorticoids (hydrocortisone) must be adjusted instead.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who works in a pharmacy presents with episodes of tiredness and lethargy. Her blood pressure is 115/75mmHg. Her bloods reveal hypokalaemia and a raised serum bicarbonate level. Urine collection reveals hypercalciuria. Otherwise, the findings are unremarkable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The findings could mimic Bartter's syndrome, which presents with hypokalaemia, metabolic alkalosis and hypercalciuria, but Bartter's is very rare (1 in a million) and usually presents before age 5 years.
  • This patient's occupation (pharmacist) provides an important clue, as access to drugs makes furosemide abuse more likely.
  • Furosemide abuse leads to hypokalaemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypercalciuria, closely resembling Bartter's syndrome but acquired rather than inherited.
  • The absence of hypertension rules out Conn's syndrome.
  • Hence, the most likely cause here is diuretic (furosemide) abuse.

Explanation for other options:

Bartter's syndrome (Option A): A Rare autosomal recessive disorder, usually presenting in childhood with hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis.

Gitelman's syndrome (Option B): Causes hypokalaemia and metabolic alkalosis but typically shows hypocalciuria, not hypercalciuria.

Conn's syndrome (Option D): Associated with hypertension and aldosterone excess, not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 26-year-old student has been recovering at home after a period of intensive care and general medical admission for meningococcal septicemia. 4 days after discharge from the hospital, she visits her treating doctor complaining of dizziness on standing and profound tiredness. On examination, she looks tired and has postural hypotension. Blood testing reveals a sodium concentration of 121 mmol/l, potassium of 6.7 mmol/l and urea of 78 mg/dl and normal urinary sodium. She has mild normochromic, normocytic anaemia. What is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is a bilateral adrenal haemorrhage occurring due to massive septicaemia, classically meningococcal infection.
  • Presents with lethargy, tiredness, and postural hypotension after severe infection.
  • Laboratory features include hyponatraemia, hyperkalaemia, elevated urea, normocytic anaemia, eosinophilia, and mild hypercalcaemia.
  • Autoimmune disease (70%) is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in the Western world, but in this case, the trigger is meningococcal sepsis.
  • Emergency management involves IV hydrocortisone and fluid replacement, even before definitive diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Secondary adrenal insufficiency (Option A): Causes adrenal failure due to pituitary/hypothalamic disease; usually shows low ACTH without hyperkalaemia.

Hypothyroidism (Option C): Can cause fatigue and anaemia but not hyperkalaemia or postural hypotension.

SIADH (Option D): Associated with hyponatraemia but shows euvolaemia without hyperkalaemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with Pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classical triad of pheochromocytoma: headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis.
  • The most common sign is hypertension (sustained or paroxysmal).
  • Additional manifestations include:
    • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy/arrhythmias due to catecholamine surge.
    • Weight loss from increased metabolism.
    • Constipation/diarrhoea from autonomic dysfunction.
    • Hyperglycemia due to catecholamine-induced insulin resistance.
    • Hypercalcemia (rare but recognised association).
    • Raynaud phenomenon from catecholamine-induced vasospasm.
    • Increased haematocrit from plasma volume contraction.
    • Orthostatic hypotension due to chronic catecholamine excess.
  • Hypokalemia is not a feature, as pheochromocytoma does not typically affect potassium handling.

Explanation of other options:

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Option B): Well-documented complication from catecholamine excess.

Raynaud phenomenon (Option C): Can occur due to episodic vasospasm induced by catecholamines.

Hypercalcemia (Option D): Reported in pheochromocytoma, especially when associated with MEN syndromes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with tremor, sweating, flushing and weight loss. On examination, his pulse is 135 bpm and his blood pressure is 160/110 mmHg. Which of the following is the least likely diagnostic possibility?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumours arising from the adrenal medulla.
    • Von Recklinghausen's disease (NF-1): Pheochromocytomas may occur, with skin neurofibromas and café-au-lait spots as key features. (Option A ruled out)
    • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL): Associated with pheochromocytomas, often alongside hemangioblastomas of the CNS and retina. (Option B ruled out)
    • Carney's triad: Includes pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma, pulmonary chondroma, and gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs). (Option D ruled out)
  • Ataxia telangiectasia is not associated with pheochromocytoma, making it the least likely diagnosis

choices.text: At the time of ligation of the left adrenal vein
Following removal of one adrenal gland
Following excision of both adrenal glands

questions.text: What is the optimum timing for the administration of hydrocortisone to a patient undergoing bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bilateral adrenalectomy is indicated in patients with recurrent/persistent disease after pituitary surgery in Cushing's disease.
  • Most surgical texts recommend that cortisol supplementation begin immediately after the removal of both adrenal glands, since endogenous cortisol production ceases at this point.
  • This ensures adequate glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement, preventing acute adrenal crisis.
  • Therefore, hydrocortisone is not required during the surgery itself, but becomes essential once both adrenal glands are excised.

Explanation of other options:

At the start of laparotomy (Option A): Giving hydrocortisone at the start of laparotomy is unnecessary since cortisol is still being secreted by the adrenal glands.

At the time of ligation of the left adrenal vein (Option B): Ligation of one adrenal vein does not immediately abolish cortisol secretion, so replacement is not required at this stage.

Following excision of both adrenal glands (Option C): After removal of one adrenal gland, the contralateral gland continues to produce sufficient cortisol.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is being treated with desmopressin for diabetes insipidus. His plasma glucose level (fasting) is 108 mg/dl, sodium 139 mmol/l (137-144), potassium 4.5 mmol/l (3.5-4.9) and calcium 10.9 mg/dl. He still has complaints of polyuria, polydipsia and nocturia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This boy most likely has nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to hypercalcemia, which causes the renal tubules to become resistant to ADH.
  • The defect may be at the vasopressin-2 receptor or a post-receptor defect involving the aquaporin-2 water channel.
  • In central diabetes insipidus (ADH deficiency), patients show a good response to desmopressin (V2 agonist), which is not seen here.
  • His findings are not suggestive of diabetes mellitus, since glucose is normal.
  • In SIADH, low sodium levels are typical, but his sodium is normal.

Explanation of other options:

Diabetes mellitus (Option A): Normal fasting glucose excludes diabetes mellitus as the cause of polyuria/polydipsia.

Central DI (Option C): Would improve with desmopressin therapy, unlike nephrogenic DI.

SIADH (Option D): Typically presents with hyponatremia, which is not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with Addison's disease is intolerant of her hydrocortisone treatment, which she takes at a dose of 15 mg in the morning and 5 mg in the evening. Which of the following doses of prednisolone would provide an equivalent daily dose to her hydrocortisone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The equivalent dose of prednisolone compared to hydrocortisone therapy is usually about 25% of the hydrocortisone dose.
  • 20 mg hydrocortisone = 5 mg prednisolone = 4 mg methylprednisolone = 0.75 mg dexamethasone.
  • Adequacy of steroid replacement is usually assessed by clinical well-being and restoration of normal (not excessive) weight.
  • In primary adrenal insufficiency, both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids are required.
  • In secondary adrenal insufficiency, only glucocorticoids are required.

questions.text: An 8-day-old baby presents with vomiting, poor feeding and loose stools. On examination, his heart rate is 190 bpm, BP 50/30 mmHg and respiratory rate 72 breaths/min. Blood tests: Hb 15 g/dl (13-18), sodium 120 mmol/l (137-144), potassium 6.0 mmol/l (3.5-4.9), chloride 80 mmol/l (95-107), bicarbonate 15 mmol/l (21-28), urea 30 mg/dl and creatinine 0.6 mg/dl (both normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presentation of vomiting, dehydration, shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis is highly suggestive of salt-wasting congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).
  • The most common cause is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, leading to impaired cortisol and aldosterone synthesis.
  • Aldosterone deficiency results in Na+loss, K+ retention and metabolic acidosis, as seen in this case.
  • The acute presentation with hypotension and shock is typical of salt-wasting crisis in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels.

Explanation of other options:

Acute tubular necrosis (Option B): Usually presents with elevated urea and creatinine, which are normal here.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (Option C): Presents later (2-8 weeks), with projectile non-bilious vomiting and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.

Galactosaemia (Option D): Manifests with jaundice, hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, not hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.
